I did hear, yeah, a lot of people were encouraged to come after I left but I wasnt the one that put myself on the news. We didnt want to be on the news. UK authorities now face the dficult question of what to doMs Begum manages toto Britain. Her familys lawyer, Tasnime Akunjee, said he anticipated that she would face criminal proceedings upon anyto the UK, but said it was the familys hope that she would be given professional help following her experience in Syria.  He told BBC Breakfast: The family have gone out of their way from day one to try to get her away from the IS narrative and the context which she finds herself in. Shes been there for four years and we would be surprisedshe hadnt been further damaged beyond the degree she had already been groomed into. The family are concerned, as they have been for the last four years, not just to get her away, but, as of yesterday, to make sure that their grandchild - her child - is not influenced by that sort of thinking.

title: dundee jobs boost as decommissioning firms pledge 5m expansion in city
story: Dundee has been given a jobs boost after a decommissioning firm pledged a £m expansion in the city.Metal recycling, decommissioning and steel tubulars specialist, John Lawrie Group, has agreed a multi-million pound deal to develop a new site at the Port of Dundee.The Aberdeen-headquartered company has reached an agreement with Forth Ports to establish a new metal recycling and decommissioning base at the Port.Both organisations will invest in the project, which will see an existing two-acre site at the city port redeveloped to create a new purpose-built concrete pad.The site will support the existing supply chain in Dundee in delivering oil and gas and decommissioning projects in the city.A combined investment of about £million is being made by both businesses in the development, which covers construction costs, the long-term lease of the site and the purchase of plant and equipment.John Lawrie Group will use the site to dismantle redundant offshore infrastructure brought ashore during oil and gas decommissioning projects and also for metal processing operations.Scheduled to be up and running in early , the facility will be operated by John Lawrie Group’s metals ision.  At launch, up to  new full-time jobs will be created, with the prospect of further posts being added as operations at the site develop.John Lawrie Group, which annually processes around , tonnes of metal, has been involved in the decommissioning sector for over  years.During that time it has handled piece small items from repair and modication projects, to piece large items brought ashore as part of entire  or field decommissioning programmes.John Lawrie Group, which operates metal recycling facilities in Aberdeen, Montrose, Evanton near Invergordon and Lerwick on Shetland, has previously carried out decommissioning work at the Port of Dundee.In , it dismantled a -tonne offshore module at the port, with the materials then being transported to the firm’s Aberdeen metal recycling facility where the redundant North Sea structure was fully processed and recycled.Dave Weston, John Lawrie Metals managing director, said: “This is a signicant investment for John Lawrie Group and comes  months after we acquired a metal recycling facility on Shetland.#It underlines our commitment to support the oil and gas decommissioning sector and forms part of our long-term strategy to develop John Lawrie Group’s operations across the country.#Operating facilities in close proximity to Scotland’s major ports also acknowledges the strategic importance we see them continuing to play as part of the country’s infrastructure.#Over the coming  months we will be working closely with all of the relevant authorities and licensing bodies as we finalise plans for this development in Dundee.#Our aim is to maximise the amount of materials that are reused and recycled, in order to minimise the volume of waste sent to landfill, helping to create a greener and more sustainable economy.”Led by Forth Ports and public-private partnership, Dundeecom, work is underway to position Dundee as an integrated hub for North Sea oil and gas decommissioning work.Boasting deep-water berths and a strategic east coast location, it is hoped Dundee will secure a sizeable portion of the £.billion that is forecast to be spent on decommissioning oil and gas infrastructure from the UK Continental Shelf over the next decade.David Webster, Forth Ports’ Senior Port Manager for Dundee and Leith, said: “This is a major milestone in Forth Ports’ strategy to develop a full service oil and gas decommissioning hub here at the Port of Dundee.“We are excited to be working with John Lawrie Group to develop this new decommissioning facility.  We have worked closely together on a number of projects and the company’s commitment to reuse and recycling and its strong track record is evident.#The opening of the facility in early  will be a very visible sign of the Port of Dundee’s ambition to support the North Sea oil and gas decommissioning sector.”Callum Falconer, CEO of Dundeecom, added: “John Lawrie Group is a long-established and highly regarded company that has an extensive track record of innovative thinking in oil and gas decommissioning.#It is great to welcome the company to Dundee on a permanent basis, where it will complement the existing supply chain.#John Lawrie Group’s decision to locate here is a real vote of confidence for the city as it seeks to continue to ersy its economy and establish itself as an important decom hub.”Established in Aberdeen as a metal merchant, John Lawrie Group now offers a erse range of industrial services across its metals, tubulars and decom isions. The firm specialises in metal recycling and reprocessing, the supply of new and used steel tubulars, and the provision of industrial and oilfield decommissioning services. John Lawrie Group employs an -strong workforce across operations in the UK, America and Europe.  In , John Lawrie Group was acquired by its management in partnership with Rubicon Partners, a leading industrial investor, and principal investment firm Grovepoint.  For more information about John Lawrie Group, visit www.johnlawrie or telephone  .

title: dundee move was easy decision for aberdeens scott wright to make
story: Leaving a squad challenging at the top of the table for one struggling at the bottom may seem like a big decision for any young footballer to make.One that you might need a bit of time to think over.For Dundee’s on-loan winger Scott Wright, however, a phone call to Dens Park boss Jim McIntyre was all it took to convince him to head down from Aberdeen.And just two games into his temporary switch to dark blue, the Scotland U  international is already convinced his snap decision was the right one.“I’m loving it here and all the boys are making me feel really welcome. Now it’s a question of getting settled in as quick as I can and just playing football,” he said.“I had obviously spoken to Derek McInnes and he said to speak to Jim McIntyre before making any decision.“The gaffer at Aberdeen left it up to me.“He told me he’d love to have me still up there butI wanted to go and get games he understood.“So I spoke to the gaffer here on the phone and I loved everything he had to say. I jumped at the chance to come down here.”And the -year-old sees the draws against Hamilton and Kilmarnock since he arrived as proof this is a squad that can pull away from the relegation zone between now and the end of the season.“The only frustrating thing for me so far is that we’ve not taken six points out of six from the two games I’ve been involved in but I think all the fans and us as a team can feel from those performances that we are building momentum.“In the Hamilton game it was a case of everyone trying to get used to each other. A lot of us had only come in right before the deadline and we only really had one training session together.“It was about trying to get to know everyone’s games, their personalities. I think we are all starting to gel now and you can see that on the pitch.“Not having a game last weekend because we’re out of the cup has given us a bit more time to work on that. That gives us a better picture going into the game against Livingston this weekend.”Today’s trip to the Tony Macaroni Arena to face Livingston is a meeting with a team who have taken the Premiership by storm this term but have been struggling for a win of late.Since thumping Hearts - in mid-December, Gary Holt’s team have not won in eight outings. Wright does not see that as a sign this could be an easy  minutes for Dundee.“We have to treat it that every game from now on is going to be a big game for us and this will be.“We know how Livi will be and they will work hard but all we can do is just prepare the way we want to and work on how we can play. Hopefully, that will be enough.“They haven’t won in a few games but it’s a testimony to Livi how many points they have. They started the season so well.”Today, of course, will see Dundee asked to play on Livi’s much-criticised plastic pitch.The debate over their use has surfaced again this week via the PFA canvassing their members for views on them. While Wright is very much in the camp that prefers grass surfaces, the articial surface is not something he’s going to gripe about.“All we can do is get on with it and we are not going to use the pitch as an excuse,” he added.“Playing in Scotland, you get used to them.“However, I think having everyone playing on grass is something that would benefit the top league.“You prepare for a team each week but, for these games, you also have to prepare for the pitch as well.“All we can do as players is give our opinion about them.”

title: dundee residents physically sick after sea of human waste comes through pipes in their homes
story: Resident on a city street have been physically sick after a “sea of human waste” came through the pipes in their homes.Carol Kilburn and neighbour Gail Taylor say they have had enough of the disgusting problem in their Dens Road properties.The sludge has seeped through the pipes over the last two weeks and homes have been left stinking as a result.The pair have contacted their landlords, the environmental health department and Scottish Water about the issue.The problem is not only in the flats, with the waste also running down the side of the building and into the garden.Carol said: “There have been issues with the main drain and pipe system at the back. It’s a sea of human waste.“The pipes connect the properties at numbers , ,  and .“The water and diarrhoea substance has been coming up through the kitchen sink and the bath. You can actually hear it moving through the system.”Carol added: “It’s reached the stage now where I’m not prepared to cook meals in my own home.“We’ve had family over to visit and they’ve been physically sick with the smell.”A spokesman for Scottish Water said: “In response to reports from customers experiencing sewage backing up within tenement flats on Dens Road, our sewer response team has attended and investigated.“The problem has been found to be within the building’s private drains which are the joint responsibility of the owners of the flats.“We have provided advice to customers and to Dundee City Council to assist in getting the matter resolved.“We appreciate that the situation is very unpleasant for the customers affected. The work to resolve the problem in this case needs to be carried out by a plumber working on behalf of the owners of the flats.”

title: emergency crews rush to tay road bridge after woman climbs over barrier onto ledge
story: Emergency services rushed to the Tay Road Bridge last night after a young woman was spotted on the outside ledge, having climbed over the barrier.Fire, police, ambulance, coastguard teams as well as the Broughty Ferry leboat crew were alerted by bridge staff,Staff were concerned the -year-old, who was from Kirkcaldy, was about to jump and closed the bridge and went to her aid.According to Police Scotland the bridge staff were able to talk her to safety before handing her over to a waiting ambulance.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: “There was concern for the woman who was spotted on the outside edge of the road bridge at .pm.“She had climbed over the railing and bridge staff were concerned she was going to jump.“Emergency services were alerted but bridge staff managed to get her to safety before the emergency crews arrived.

title: gomis set to take over as dundee united target hat trick of wins down at queen of the south
story: Veteran Morgaro Gomis is set to take over in midfield when Dundee United try to make it three wins on the bounce as they head for Queen of the South today.The -year-old is expected to replace Calum Butcher, who will serve the first game of a two-match ban after his red card in the Scottish Cup win at St Mirren last weekend.His second game on the sidelines will be the cup quarter-final against Ross County or Inverness Caley Thistle which has been confirmed for Sunday, March  at pm.The game is also being televised live on BBC Scotland.As well as continuing their recent winning run, the Tangerines will be looking for their third success of the campaign over Queens.To do that, though, manager Robbie Neilson is well aware they will have to keep in-form home striker Stephen Dobbie quiet.His spectacular strike in the cup at Aberdeen on Sunday was the -year-old’s th goal in just  appearances this term.“He has been on fire lately and someone we will have to get to grips with,” said Robbie.“He has a lot of quality, he knows how to score goals.“He’s just a very good player and I think he has the freedom of Dumfries these days. He’s a god down there.”United have their own in-form attacker in the shape of Pavol Safranko.The Slovakian, who’s on loan from Aalborg, has hit the net three times in his last four games.That’s taken his tally so far to  goals and he’s scored on the two previous occasions he’s faced the Doonhamers.“We been playing well and we’re looking for that to continue,” added Robbie.

title: livingston may be off form but dundee boss jim mcintyre expects a tough test today
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is taking nothing for granted when his improving team face off-form Livingston at the Tony Macaroni Arena today.The Dark Blues head over the Forth on the back of displays against Hamilton and Kilmarnock that, but for injury time mishaps, would have earned six points instead of two.An injury-time equaliser cost victory at Accies while the chance to take maximum points against Killie last week slipped away when Kenny Miller’s penalty was saved in the fth minute of time added on.Now it’s on to Livi, who’ve not won since before the winter break but Jim believes Gary Holt’s team remain formidable opponents.“It’s natural that at some stage of a season you will have a dip and they’ve still had a brilliant season. They have some very good players,” he said.“The first thing we have to do is try to win our battles but don’t forget they have scored some quality goals, some good team goals.“We have to try to make sure inidually we get the better of them and try to go and create opportunities to win the game.”Dundee go into the clash with controversy over plastic pitches like Livi’s rekindled by a PFA survey showing top-flight players are unied in opposition to them.The manager is also in that camp but hasn’t forgotten that defeat at the Tony Macaroni in his first game in charge was down to what happened in the air and not the surface.That day back in October his team conceded four goals from set pieces.“We didn’t deal with set plays and that killed us. It was an eye-opener that day in terms of what we had to work with,” he said.“There’s no doubt, though, the surface is an advantage. I was the manager of a team, Queen of the South, who had an articial surface andyou train on it every day it’s a definite help.“At the same time I’m not trying to detract from how well Livingston have done because they’ve done exceptionally well.”Dundee are still nursing a few niggling injuries from that Killie draw, but it’s hoped everyone who was on duty then will be available. Midfielder Ethan Robson is expected to recover in time from the groin injury that forced him to miss that game.

title: tayside cops charge boy 15 after cars vandalised on hogmanay
story: Police in Tayside have charged a boy after a number of cars were vandalised on Hogmanay.The -year-old boy been charged in relation to a number of vandalisms to cars in the Dunning Street area of Bridge Of Earn on Hogmanay.A police statement said: #We would like to thank the residents of the area and the numerous witnesses and further complainers who responded to our initial appeal for information back at the beginning of January # your help has been invaluable, and very much appreciated.#

title: three strikers almost missed dees win against livingston
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre has revealed he was close to being without his entire strikeforce for Saturday’s vital win at Livingston.The Dark Blues picked up three points to move out of the bottom two in the Premiership for the first time since August and main strikers Andrew Nelson, Craig Curran and Kenny Miller all played their part.However, it wasn’t until late on Friday the manager was sure they would be available.“Nelson had not trained all week. He took a bang on the shinand it went into his calf,” said Jim.“The swelling was in a deep compartment and we couldn’t sht it so he was a major doubt. The first day he trained was Friday.“Kenny Miller missed two days with illness and Craig Curran was on the treatment table most of the week, as was Ethan Robson.“It wasn’t looking great in terms of having to pick the same team again. I’m delighted they all pulled through and I thought we deserved the victory.”Nelson did have to come off immediately after scoring a second-half equaliser when his leg seized up but he is expected to make Friday night’s clash with Hibs at Dens Park.That game will represent a chance to move three points ahead of second-bottom Hamilton and stretch the gap to basement boys St Mirren to eight points.Right now, Dundee are ahead of Accies on goal dference but, for Jim, it’s not where they are right now that counts.“It’s nice but it doesn’t matter, as long as we are out the bottom two in May. There’s going to be ups and downs, I’ve said that before.“The three teams are all battling. Look at St Mirren going up to Aberdeen and picking up a point.“So, yes, it’s great for confidence but you could be back in it the next week.“Until you start to put a run of games, a run of victories together, you have just got to concentrate on the next game.”Livi, who played most of the  minutes with  men after Shaun Byrne’s early red card were left furious when they were denied a late penalty for a Jesse Curran tackle on Steven Lawless.To rub salt in their wounds, referee Greg Aitken booked the home player for ing.

title: united put pressure on top two with win against queen of the south
story: Dundee United boss Robbie Neilson hailed his side’s defensive work at Queen of the South as they put the pressure on the top two of Ayr and Ross County.Nicky Clark’s first-half penalty was enough to bring the Tangerines to within three points of leaders Ross County on Saturday.It wasn’t all plain sailing against  men, though, as the Doonhamers put Neilson’s men under the cosh in the second period.The United boss said: “It’s only ourselves and Morton who have won there this season so we knew to go there and get three points was going to be tough.“Even when they went down to  men it was tough.“When there’s a strikeforce of Stephen Dobbie and Lyndon Dykes up top then there is always going to be problems caused and issues. I’m just pleased to get three points.“When teams go down to  men they can go a bit gung ho – they went three at the back with four in the middle and kept Dykes and Dobbie up top.“It was hard to deal with but I don’t feel like there were any clear-cut chances from them.“There were shots from distance and yes, they hit the bar butit goes in it’s a wonder goal.”He added: “It’s a massive win for us. With  games to go, we are a point behind Ayr and three off Ross County and we’ve put some pressure on them as well.”Queens boss Gary Naysmith said: “That’s the way it’s going for us right now, we’re not getting any breaks. We made one bad decision in the game.“The ref got it right but it’s about the only decision he got right all game.“You can never be happy getting beat but to play probably the best team in the league with  men and put in that performance I have to take the positives.”

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Cycle ride aims to help Highlands special needs charity
story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. It provides warmth, security, comfort, friendship and caring when needed.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Date finally set for demolition of eyesore Eastgate Hostel in Inverness
story: WORK is finally set to start on tackling the fire-ravaged Eastgate Hostel in Inverness ndash almost SIX years after the blaze.A start date of March  has been set to begin the demolition of the High Street building which has been shrouded in scaffolding to the frustration of nearby businesses and community leaders for years.The announcement follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which has kept up the pressure in calling for action and ensuring the issue has remained in the headlines ndash and not forgotten.A spokesman for the owners said following successful negotiations with a demolition contractor the work would begin to take down the frontage of the building and remove the fire-damaged interiors.It is expected to take up to  weeks.Work would start five years and  months after the blaze in April .Community and business leaders have welcomed the news.Crown and City Centre Community Council chairwoman Pat Hayden welcomed the announcement but wondered why work had not started in mid January as previously expected.ldquoI am sorry to say I will only believe it when the workmen are on site, ldquo said Mrs Hayden who congratulated the Inverness Courier for keeping up the pressure since the building was damaged in April .Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding .ldquoThe reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment made by the owners to invest in this key site,she said.Central ward councillor Bet McAllister said it would especially help businesses in the High Street.ldquoI am also heartened to hear of the ongoing commitment to ensure that a replacement building is constructed at the earliest opportunity, she said.But chiropodist Jim Crawford whose business is nearby remained unconvinced. ldquoThere have been so many  dawns, he said. ldquoIf it doesnrsquot start by March , the council should take it over.A spokesman for the buildingrsquos owners said specialist contractors will initially remove asbestos from the site before the scaffolding is removed.The plan is that each stone for the front will be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.The spokesman said the current contract is for the demolition to facilitate the removal of the scaffolding, but the intention was to rebuild fairly soon afterwards.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness mentoring project aims to improve lives
story: AN INVERNESS mentoring programme is among the projects set to benefit from a pound million windfall for communities across the Highlands.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell visited Charleston Academy as she announced the funding under the Scottish Governmentrsquos Aspiring Communities Fund.She met staff and pupils involved with a programme which sees young people mentor younger children at Kinmylies Primary School and Nursery.Charleston is one of nine Highland schools taking part in the Growinggether in the Community scheme run by Forres-based Ecologia Youth Trust which has been awarded pound,.During her visit, Ms Campbell heard from pupils how the scheme is helping to increase their wellbeing and confidence as well as strengthening community links.Jake Weston , who is among those who have taken part, mentored a young boy who was initially isolated from other children.ldquoHe was able to make friends and share lunch at the table with other children which he had not done previously, he said.ldquoI have gained a lot of confidence.Logan Parkersaid she had also grown in confidence.ldquoI would recommend it definitely ndash  per cent, she said.Ms Campbell said local communities understood what worked in their own areas and the funding would enable them to help create a more equal Scotland.ldquoIt will support organisations across the Highlands and Islands to deliver tangible, innovative approaches to improve lives based on local priorities and will address poverty and inequality in their area, she said.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness pupils show winning ways in business competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Last phase of Ness Islands work to take place next week
story: The final phase of improvement works on the Ness Islands is set to resume next week.Highland Councilrsquos city of Inverness area committee approved pound, of common good funding for improvement works on bridges, tree maintenance, pathways and bank erosion works, to take place in stages over  months.This final phase will start on Monday, concentrating on restructuring and repairing paths leading up to some of the bridges to enable smoother access for wheelchairs and prams.As part of this work the Wells Bridge will be closed for around a week.Other routes around the islands will still be accessible.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: New Nairn homes help meet demand
story: An affordable housing scheme in Nairn has welcomed its first residents, after Albyn Housing Society took handover of the development.The  new-build homes in Farnack Street have been allocated for affordable rent via the Highland Housing Register, providing much-needed accommodation for local applicants.This included a specially adapted property to support the needs of -year-old Shauni McCallum and her family.The new home is adapted to be wheelchair accessible, and also benefits from the inclusion of a large en-suite wet room with hoist provision and a carport.Her mother Myra Wardhaugh said: ldquoOur new home was specially adapted for Shaunirsquos requirements and we canrsquot even begin to express what a dference it has made.ldquoWe can now enjoy spending time in the home, as a family, without any added stress.Albyn Housing Society worked with contractor Springfield Properties to deliver the project in just  months.The new housing development represents a total investment of almost pound. million, with Scottish Government support totalling more than half that amount.Society chief executive Calum Macaulay said: ldquoWe have ambitious build plans for the coming years as we strive to meet growing demand for affordable homes.In the past year, the society has completed affordable housing developments in Inverness, Kirkhill, Alness and where.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen held 2 2 by premierships bottom side st mirren
story: ABERDEEN suffered a damaging - draw with the Premiership#s bottom side St Mirren at Pittodrie in a match also marred by an injury to defender Tommie Hoban.Dropping points at home to the team rock bottom of the table will be hammer blow to their chances of overtaking second placed Rangers in the Premiership.The only positive, albeit minor, is that the Dons did not lose ground on Rangers who were held - by St Johnstone.A dismal day for the Reds was made even worse when on loan Watford defender Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury late in the first half.Aberdeen fell behind to a penalty from Duckens Nazon before Lewis Ferguson headed an equalizer in the first half.However Buddies went ahead again through a strike from Kyle McAllister before a goal from prolic scorer Sam ruled out with an ankle injury sustained in that cup victory.He was replaced by Mikey Devlin who made his first Aberdeen starts since a - defeat of Hibs on November .Devlin had been ruled out for three months with a foot tendon injury.Following his impressive sht as a half-time substitute in the cup tie Niall McGinn was handed a start with Stevie May dropping to the bench.Aberdeen should have netted the opener in the th minute when McGinn#s corner kick from the left found Lewis Ferguson racing in at the back post but he headed wide from eight yards out.Moments later McGinn raced onto a clever through ball from Mackay-Steven.Racing towards the by-line McGinn drilled a low, inviting cross along the face of goal but there were no takers.However it was relegation battling St Mirren who went ahead in the th minute when goal machine Sam Cosgrove, on  goals in the last  games, tugged down Paul McGinn.Referee Craig Thomson awarded a penalty that was converted by Duckens NAZON who fired equalized in the nd minute when a corner from Mackay-Steven was flicked on by Mikey Devlin to the back post.Teenager FERGUSON had drted in unchecked and clinically headed home from eight yards.The Reds should have gone ahead moments later when Stewart squared a pass to McGinn but with the goal beckoning he scooped a shot over from  yards.Aberdeen suffered an injury set-back in the rd minute when on loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury.The defender went down when his studs looked to have caught in the surface going for the ball in front of the Main Stand.There was no contact with a St Mirren player as he appeared to twist awkwardly.Clearly in distress Hoban received treatment on the pitch before being stretchered off.It was the latest injury blow for the Watford defender who has only recently ed from five months out following shoulder surgery in August.Hoban also missed the whole of the previous season having suffered  a knee cruciate ligament injury that required surgery.St Mirren should have gone ahead soon after the break when Kyle McAllister#s cross from the right found Brad Lyons unmarked  yards out but his header flashed inches wide of the near post.Slack play when trying to move the ball out of defence was punished by St Mirren in the st minute when a loose pass was intercepted.Buddies raced up field and Lyons found McALLISTER who fired a magnicent,  unstoppable shot from just inside the penalty box into the far corner beyond Joe Lewis.The Reds drew level  in the th minute when COSGROVE met a cross from the left side with his  and clinically slotted home from  yards out for his th goal of the season.Aberdeen had a strong penalty claim when substitute Connor McLennan appeared to be brought down in the box in the th minute but referee Craig Thomson waved play on.Moments later Cosgrove should have put the Dons ahead when he met a Stewart cross in a great position only to fire an effort wide.ABERDEEN: Lewis, title: aberdeen msp welcomes additional loan funding for gps
story: A north-east MSP has welcomed a funding boost to GP practices.The Scottish Government announced that an additional £ million support will be given to surgeries across Scotland to help with running costs.Called the GP Premises Sustainability Loan Scheme, it aims to ease the financial burden for owners, who can apply for long-term interest-free loans up to % of the building’s value.More than  practices in the country have applied so far – around % of the total amount eligible.Aberdeen Central MSP Kevin Stewart said: “Folk in Aberdeen will welcome this signicant investment in our local NHS service, which will help family doctors deal with the costs of running their practice.“The extra investment will encourage more people to join the profession – which will in turn make it easier for practices in Scotland to retain and recruit staff.“The Scottish Government will always protect and support our NHS and I encourage eligible GPs in Aberdeen to consider whether they could benefit from this scheme.”It began in November  and was previously backed with £m of funding, which has now been raised to £m before April .The loan is repayable when the premises is changed or sold.

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: human rights monitor philppa bonella speaks at ms centre
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowSt Margaret’s Justice and Peace Group invited Philppa Bonella to Lochgilphead on Tuesday February  to talk about her experiences as a human rights monitor on the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel .She was in the Holy Land for three months last year and spent time on the West Bank in Palestinian villages surrounded by Israeli settlements.Philippa told her audience that the EAPPI sends batches of people of all nationalities to the Holy Land for these three-month stints, where the monitors are split into small groups and must operate in pairs for safety.She recalled particular incidents – schools tear-gassed by Israeli troops, homes searched in raids during the middle of the night, families prevented from picking their olives, Palestinian villages surrounded by Israelis in mobile homes, supported by Israeli government-funded water and electricity supplies.Human rights monitors must be impartial and Philippa did her utmost to present a balanced picture and all EAPPI monitors share their findings and experiences with the UN with the intention of furthering solutions in this troubled region. Her conclusions drawn from experience was that when the monitors were around, there may have been unpleasant situations, but no tragedies. When there was no monitor around – clearly defined by their unorms – people died.Philippa had only been home for eight weeks when she spoke to the Justice and Peace Group, and she admitted that she was still processing the often brutal and violent scenes she had witnessed. And though she wryly joked that it had not exactly been a picnic, she encouraged her audience to become involved in the work of EAPPI – through prayer, support, even by volunteering to be a monitor .For more information, visit eappi.org en or visit the EAPPI Facebook page @EAPPI.WCCPIC:Her stories of the hardships in Israel kept visitors engaged. no_aholylandPhillipa Bonella speaking at the MS Centre. no_aholyland

title: ayr pub look revive nightlife
story: NewsAyr pub look to revive nightle with music in beer gardenArthur Street Kitchen applied for permission to host live al fresco entertainment in the town centre.ShareBySarah Hilley:,  FEB News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pub operator wants to revive Ayr’s former nightle strip with music in a large beer garden. Arthur Street Kitchen applied for permission to host live al fresco entertainment in the town centre. But councillors worried about noise want to carry out a site visit before making a decision. The venue’s manager Andy McPherson said: “We would like to have entertainment for customers in the garden this summer.” He said the music would not be too loud as the business is aware of residents living in the Arthur Street area of the town. Appearing before the South Ayrshire Council licensing board, he added: “We are hoping to reinvigorate Arthur Street. It is starting to come to le again.” Board chair Craig Mackay said: “Noise is the main issue here. “We would be looking for a noise report.” Mr McPherson said it would be background music featuring a musician playing acoustic guitar, for example. Ayr manager John Neil told the meeting no noise complaints were made last summer. The restaurant and pub also want to have a large screen to show sport and films. Arthur Street Kitchen is based in the former West of the Moon premises and beside the Vinyl night club. Councillor Mackay said: “The West of the Moon was a family space. What you are proposing is quite dferent.” Mr Neil said Arthur Street Kitchen still caters for children. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: centenary celebrations troons charles kerr
story: S pupils Abbie Rankine left and Neve Gooding at the bust of the founder Charles Kerr Marr."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCharles Kerr Marr, retired coal contractor and formerly from Troon, boarded his train in London to Perthshire on Sunday January , , and little did he know his two week shooting and fishing break in Scotland would prove fatal for him, writes Nan McFarlane. His death revealed he had left his entire fortune in his will to his native town of Troon. His legacy would provide education awards and grants for the people of the town along with a new public school. As Marr’s train travelled north he decided to break his journey, to pay a visit to his sister in Girvan. He was close to his sister Helen and visited her often after her marriage to ColonelABGrant, owner of Killochan Castle estate at Girvan, who was also a senior partner in the firm of Grant Somerville  Co in London and was later ordained as Revd. Grant in the Church of Scotland. Marr had intended to spend part of his fortnight at Girvan but extended his stay to a month. Perhaps his change of heart was due to the widespread unrest taking place in Glasgow at that time. The January of  saw the so-called ‘Harbour Riots’, where racial confrontations were breaking out between black and white merchant seamen on the town’s quayside and spreading into the town. A four day General Strike was called for on January  and four days later George Square was crammed with tens of thousands of angry workmen. Crowds of unemployed men joined in the fracas for a  hour working week. As tempers flared the army was deployed, troops brought in tanks and armored vehicles to control the crowds. As tensions heightened it was not an environment travellers would want to find themselves caught up in. Eventually CK Marr left Girvan on Saturday February  for his onward journey north to his annual shooting and fishing break in Perthshire. As the train made its way towards the city he took ill with acute appendicitis. When taken off the train at the Central Station he was rushed to the Glasgow Nursing Home, but it was already too late as he tragically died in the operating theatre. There is little known of Charles Kerr Marr, despite having a successful career in the coal exporting business. Born on October , , at  Welbeck Crescent, Troon, he was the third son of Captain John Marr, master of the merchant ship ‘Reciprocity’, sailing between Troon and Canada. John Marr and his we Amelia had five children, sons William, John and Charles, along with two daughters, Helen and Amelia. Up to the age of ten, Charles attended the Parish School in Academy Street at Troon, going on to join his two brothers at Irvine Royal Academy to complete his education. On finishing his schooling, Marr was apprenticed at A  J Guthrie, Coal Agents at Troon Harbour. Unlike his brother John, who followed in his father’s footsteps to become a sea captain, Marr left home as soon as his apprenticeship ended, to work as a Commercial Clerk with Kitstons, Iron Merchants in Glasgow. Moving later to take up the position of cashier at Clyde Ironworks, only to leave a short time later to be manager of the firm of GrantSomerville  Co in London. The move may have been influenced by A B Grant, who was a senior partner in the company and married to his sister Helen. By the time he met his future we, some years later, there is no evidence as to when he moved back to Glasgow, or indeed any explanation found as to his change of occupation. Marr is recorded in the Scotland census of  as residing in Renfrew Street in Glasgow and again on his marriage certicate a year later, where he is also recorded as being employed as a Soft Goods Warehouseman.  Little is known as to why he left coal exporting to go into the Drapery business, or where he met and fell in love with his we Agnes Murray Kinghorn. However, Agnes’s father was a General Merchant, so it would seem likely he met her in his line of work. Charles and Agnes married on March ,  and set up home at Sutherland Terrace in Glasgow’s Hillhead. Unfortunately, after only  months of married le, Agnes tragically died of Phthisis Pulmonalis . She was just  years of age. Her death was a severe blow to Marr, leaving him brokenhearted and distraught, which had a profound effect on him. Shortly after he laid his we to rest, he had thought of going abroad to work, but instead accepted an appointment with Hull Blyth  Company of London. Within a year he was made a partner in the company when he developed the firm’s export trade. His work of establishing depots in numerous ports in the world gave him an opportunity to travel abroad, especially to China and Japan, where he found an interest in collecting oriental treasures. During his time with Hull Blyth the firm went on to become one of the largest shipping charterers in the UK. Charles Kerr Marr played a signicant part in the company’s worldwide success. Charles Marr moved to London after his we’s death, he never again owned a house. All his years in London, he alternated between two clubs, the Athenaeum and the Constitutional. The nearest he came to having a home was in his later years, when he rented two rooms in Camden House at Chislehurst in Kent, which was originally built for Napoleon the rd. Just being there helped him to relax and take up golf. He was reputed to be good company with a great sense of humour and well known to be very generous. Marr was a lover of the arts and music and in all that time he rarely spoke of his we, or of her death and he never remarried, even his closest friends assumed he was a bachelor. When he retired in  he spent a good part of each year fishing and shooting in Scotland. Two years before his untimely death, Charles Marr carefully drafted out his will in , leaving his entire fortune to the people of Troon and setting out the way it was to be carried out. Marr’s coal fortune legacy has given the town a magnicent architectural school building with playing fields the envy of the country. Marr College on its own is a fitting tribute to this man of extraordinary vision. By the time Marr College opened in  the school had attracted the most renowned academics to come and teach. It was the only grant aided school in Scotland that didn’t charge fees. A public school for every child of the town, had oak led class rooms, inlaid parquet flooring, Italian tiled corridorsa copper domed library, purple velvet drapes and teachers attired in flowing cloaks with mortar boards on their heads, this was seen by all to be a stunning,not magnicent, comprehensive school, deemed to be the best school in Scotland and envied by it. The CK Marr Educational Trust, the only one of its kind in Scotland, has provided awards or grants to hundreds of Troon students, of all ages each year. The addition of the MarrEducation Resource Centre in Troon Library, the only one then in Ayrshire, is a valuable educational resource for all who use it. Marr College and the CK Marr Educational Trust are a testimony to the wishes of Charles Kerr Marr and a fitting memorial to this great benefactor. He was buried beside his beloved we in CathcartCemetery in Glasgow. Over the past century the people of Troon owe a huge debt to custodians of Marr’s vision, the Marr Trustees, past and present. Over the decades the many Trustees, Boards of Governors and ious Clerks, Treasurers and Accountants, who have and still do today and for many decades to come, have successfully upheld the wishes of the town’s greatest ever benefactor and extraordinary visionary, Charles Kerr Marr.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnChurch of ScotlandUniversities and CollegesGlasgowEducationFishingArmed forcesLove and romanceSchoolsRenfrewTroonPerthshireGirvanAyr NewsAyr

title: junior football fans kept out
story: NewsJunior football fans kept out of the boozer before big matchThirsty Auchinleck Talbot fans forced to stay sober until nearer the kick-offShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThirst for football - Talbot fans at the match "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA lid was kept on football fan’s early hour boozing in the build up to the William Hill Scottish Cup Auchinleck Talbot game last month. A number of venues in the Auchinleck area applied to open their bars for a tipple at am on match day as Talbot geared up to face Ayr. Licensing bosses at East Ayrshire Council knocked back the flurry of applications for early morning drinking before the January  showdown. Despite the historic nature of the sporting event, the department decided to maintain their stance on trying to clamp down on excess boozing during football. The East Ayrshire Licensing board depute clerk Stuart McCall told councillors it was important to maintain the standard policy and have consistency. He pointed to Celtic and Rangers matches as examples of tense clashes requiring robust licensing rules. Mr McCall said: “The standard practice is games start early and the reason for that is to limit the amount of alcohol supporters can have.” “We all know the outcome excess alcohol can have in certain circumstances.” Congragulating Talbot, he added: “We are all delighted to see the result. “The maintenance of the policy is important so we are not accused of favouritism.” Some venues wanted to offer breakfast to supporters. Auchinleck Talbot defeated Ayr by one goal to nil. Alcohol was not permitted inside the grounds and fans were told they would be refused entryintoxicated. However the licensing board made a slight concession for the Auchinleck Talbot versus Hearts game on Sunday, February . title: meet veteran vet now towns
story: NewsMeet the veteran vet now a towns Citizen of the YearHes now the Senior Citizen of the Year in CumnockShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA veteran vet has been named Cumnock Citizen of the Year. John Senior has been an animal surgeon in the town for  years. He has also immersed himself in activities and volunteering for all sorts of causes. This week he was continuing his latest community activity as a hand bell ringer at Cumnock Old Church. John, , said: “All I want is the best for Cumnock and we are so fortunte to have so many things going on now. “I just want to make it better than it is.” The Keir McTurk Memorial Committee chose John after “much deliberation” from all the nominations. Chairman Colin Chisholm said: “John is someone who prefers to work behind the scenes rather than be at the forefront. “But his efforts for the community have proved invaluable.” John, originally from Edinburgh, has freshly retired from the Crossriggs veterinary practice in the town. When he arrived in  it was chiefly large livestock but treats mostly small animals. His we Heather, also a vet, remains involved in the management and their son Iain, the third member of the Senior family who is a vet, runs the practice. John is a very active member of the Cumnock Action Plan Committee, in which he has reformed the Cumnock Gardening Club assisted living in the arrangements for the Christmas festival and was actively involved in the poppy display marking the centenary of the end of the First World War. He is also an elder in the Trinity Church and a member of the fabric committee. John is an active member of Cumnock Business Association, a board member of the credit union and of Glaisnock Trust and Cumnock Tryst. Assistance he gives to both the Highland games committee and Camps is described as “invaluable.” But he said: “I don’t like standing on a pedestal. I prefer being in the background. “I somehow manage to find time for the things I want to do and I am not very good at sitting down doing nothing. “I enjoy being active and putting things back into a town that has supported me and given me a living for  years.” The presentation is likely to be at Dumfries House. The couple also have a son Alan, a chemical engineer in Cleethorpes, and daughter Kirsty, who works in Christian outreach in Hong Kong.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnCumnockAyrAyr NewsEdinburghChristmasChristmas gtsReligion

title: volunteers bike tackle social isolation
story: NewsVolunteers get on their bike to tackle social isolationCycling Without Age Prestwick is transforming lives of those with limited mobility in the area with their specially designed trishaw, a light three -wheeled vehcile with pedal used in Asian countries.ShareByLochlin Highet:,  FEB NewsVolunteers get on their bike to tackle social isolation "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommunity volunteers are coming together to tackle social isolation and loneliness - and their project is wheely fun. Cycling Without Age Prestwick is transforming lives of those with limited mobility in the area with their specially designed trishaw, a light three -wheeled vehcile with pedal used in Asian countries . The three-wheeled rickshaw is a little more than a ‘sofa on wheels’ as it is engineered to accommodate two passengers in the front and driven by a pilot in the rear. Those with mobility restrictions - old and young- can take a trip to the seafront, enjoy the Prestwick promenade views and have a good old natter. Now the community project, who’s base has been kindly gted by St Ninian’s Episcopal Church, are eager to find more volunteer pilots and those keen to get out on the trishaw. Chris Cheales, of Cycling Without Age Prestwick, said: “We now have two trishaws and we are in the middle of a training programme to help - people become qualied before starting the operation in spring. We offer two-hour sessions to two passengers and there is the opportunity to go for a drink, stop to chat, pet a dog or just enjoy the views. “We are looking for people with limited mobility who may or may not also struggle with loneliness and isolation and who would benefit from the freedom of feeling ‘the wind in their hair’. “Time is a wonderful gt to give anyone. The group hope to expand as the project grows and take their trishaws on tour to visit care homes in the area. Chris added: “We envisage days allocated to ‘user groups’, to include care homes, those recommended by Dementia Friendly Prestwick, retirement housing and local churches. “Trishaws are not cheap so we need ongoing help to keep all this on the road. “We are looking forward to another sunny summer and sharing the project with others.” The Prestwick Peoples Project has also benefitted those involved, helping volunteers flourish and gain confidence. Zara Crumlish has been a Young Ambassador for Cycling Without Age for six months. Zara, , said: “I’ve always wanted to ride a bike when I was younger but I didn’t have the balance. “The trishaw has helped me get my confidence up. “It gets me out and about with the community. “And I’m excited because I really can’t wait to take elderly people out and show them the Prom.” •Would you like to be trained as a Trishaw Pilot  Or a willing volunteer to be a co-pilot to accompany trips  .
